unit: Unit 7 | Inference for Quantitative Data: Means
title: Cereal Boxes
question_text:
A spokesman for a large cereal company is interested in whether a new promotion of including a toy in every box of cereal would greatly increase sales.
He figures that age would be a factor, so he selects one pair of subjects at each age range from $10$ to $79$ by increments of $5\text{ years}$.
The spokesman flips a coin to decide which of the pair gets a coupon for a free prize every time they buy a box of the cereal. After one year, each subject is asked how many boxes of that brand of cereal they bought.
The data is in the table below (scroll right to see full table):
From this data, is there convincing statistical evidence that people buy more cereal when a prize coupon is included?

solution:
This is a single sample $T$-test where the single sample being taken is the difference between the two age ranges. For example, the first data point to be used is $9-7 = 2$.

The $14$ data points are $2, 4, 0, -1, -1, 5, 6, 6, 2, 0, 1, 1, 0$, and $1$.

Put these data points into your calculator or statistical software package and run a one-sample $T$-test of $H_0: \mu = 0$ against $H_a: \mu > 0$, where $\mu$ represents the difference in sales with the prize and without.

The test results in a test statistic of $t = 2.84$ and $p = 0.0069$.

With a low $p$-value, there is evidence at the $1\%$, $5\%$, and $10\%$ levels that people who get the coupon for a free prize buy more cereal.

Thus, the correct answer is Choice 'A'.
